sense.name: rejecting something from contemplation or consideration
sense.examples: The critics' initial dismissal of the young author's novel would later embarrass them. Mary grew frustrated by their dismissal of all her proposals during the meeting. The dismissal of such worrisome thoughts was nearly impossible for Sally.

sense.name: termination from employment or service
sense.commentary: DISMISSAL[+action][+ordering][+leave][+employment] Note: orders the patient/object to leave - no option
sense.examples: The dismissal of two of his coworkers shocked Pete. Mary saw a stack of pink dismissal slips on the desk of the HR director. Accusations of stealing jewelry led to the dismissal of the servant.

sense.name: granting permission to leave
sense.commentary: DISMISSAL[+action][+permitting][+leave] Note: grants permission to the patient/object to leave
sense.examples: THe children had an early dismissal from school on Friday. Until you give the dismissal command, your dog should keep sitting. John's dismissal from the state penitentiary is next week.

sense.name: legal judgement to reject a court hearing
sense.commentary: DISMISSAL[+action][+rejecting][+legal][+hearing] Note: a specific usage related to the law
sense.examples: The judge ordered a dismissal of the case. Bob's hearing had a judgement of dismissal.
